author: Editor
title: America’s strangest food museums
text:
Last Slide Next Slide Women dressed as absinthe fairies pose in the recreation of an absinthe bar at the Museum of the American Cocktail. (Photo: Stephen Binns) 
We Americans love road trips to offbeat roadside attractions. We also love to eat. Towns across the U.S. celebrate these fancies by dedicating museums to humble foods like mustard, Jell-O and pizza. There’s even a museum that memorializes food that’s been burned to a crisp — one man’s trash is another man’s treasure, right? 
Some of the collections are large and Guinness-certified, while others only take up a few shelves. These quirky food — and drink — attractions feed both the mind and appetite. 
International Vinegar Museum Roslyn, S.D Ever wonder how vinegar is made? Walk through the process at the International Vinegar Museum in South Dakota. Among a collection of hundreds of vinegars from around the world, you’ll find hot pepper vinegar and coveted Italian balsamic with sky-high price tags. Stop at the tasting bar to sip a variety of vinegars. internationalvinegarmuseum.com 
Jell-O Gallery LeRoy, N.Y. Little-known fact: Jell-O’s inventor sold his recipe for $450 in 1899. The Jell-O Gallery, based in the famous dessert’s hometown of Leroy, N.Y., teems with trivia and artifacts that will make anyone nostalgic. Its exhibits include collections of Jell-O molds, spoons, toys, advertisements and memorabilia. A colorful Jell-O-themed arch, originally used in the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, makes a good photo op. jellogallery.org 
Pizza Brain Philadelphia Grab a slice and wander through “the largest collection of pizza memorabilia in the world” as certified by the Guinness Book of World Records . Situated in Fishtown, one of Philadelphia’s hippest neighborhoods, Pizza Brain’s exhibits include conversation-starters like a USS Enterprise-shaped stainless steel pizza cutter and a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Pizza Drop arcade game. An attached kitchen serves up pizza that has been named among America’s best. pizzabrain.org 
Wyandot Popcorn Museum Wyandot, Ohio The average American eats a whopping 51 quarts of popcorn each year. Explore the history of the centuries-old snack at Ohio’s Popcorn Museum, where restored antique popcorn wagons and machines are on display in a space that evokes a big top circus. Visitors receive a free box of popcorn at the end of the tour, and children even receive kernels to try to grow their own. wyandotpopcornmus.com 
Mill City Museum Minneapolis A museum dedicated to wheat seems simple enough, but this Minneapolis landmark takes the grain to another level. Nicknamed the “Best-Smelling Museum Ever Created,” the Mill City Museum tells the story of wheat, from farm to table. Once the largest flour mill in the world, the building now houses a baking lab and an eight-story “Flour Tower” elevator ride featuring historic stories and photos. Don’t miss one of the best views in town from the rooftop observation deck. mnhs.org/visit 
Idaho Potato Museum Blackfoot, Idaho The simple spud gets its moment in the spotlight at the Idaho Potato Museum. Learn the difference between a potato chip and a crisp — the collection includes the world’s largest potato crisp, clocking in at 23 inches wide and 920 calories. Exhibits include potato history, a guide to the growing and harvesting process, and potato trivia. Did you know that Thomas Jefferson first introduced “French fries” to America when he served them at a White House dinner? idahopotatomuseum.com 
National Mustard Museum Middleton, Wis. Forget deciding between ketchup and mustard. With 5,600 mustard varieties from 50 states and 70 countries, you’ll have plenty of decisions to make at Wisconsin’s National Mustard Museum. Learn how to cook with mustard, watch mustard-themed flicks in the Mustardpiece Theatre, and check out vintage mustard advertisements. Not only is admission free, but the museum’s mustard tasting bar offers samples at no charge. mustardmuseum.com 
Museum of the American Cocktail New Orleans Fittingly situated in New Orleans, the Museum of the American Cocktail illustrates the history of the cocktail since its invention 200 years ago. The collection includes iconic glassware, centuries-old bottles, rare bartending books and a 5-foot-tall robotic cocktail shaker. It’s also home to the largest collection of absinthe artifacts in the USA and features a recreation of the storied Old Absinthe House in the French Quarter. Designate a driver because the museum hosts regular events and classes. cocktailmuseum.org 
Burnt Food Museum Arlington, Mass. The motto at the Burnt Food Museum goes: “To cook the museum way — always leave the flame on low and then take a long nap.” After charring a pot of apple cider into a freestanding chunk of cinder, founder Deborah Henson-Conant began a collection of burnt food. Highlights include “hashblacks,” a “thrice-baked potato” and blackened green beans. burntfoodmuseum.com 
The Big Mac Museum Restaurant North Huntingdon, Pa. Every day is a celebration of one of America’s most iconic sandwiches at Pennsylvania’s Big Mac Museum Restaurant. Since 2007, when the famous burger turned 40, the museum has featured a look at the history of the Big Mac and its role as a pop culture icon through hands-on exhibits. Plus, it’s home to the world’s tallest Big Mac statue, a state-of-the-art jungle-themed PlayPlace and a full-service McDonald’s restaurant. bigmacmuseum.com 
Beer Can Museum Northampton, Mass. For the 21+ crowd, the Beer Can Museum in Massachusetts is a sight to behold. Owner Al Drew has amassed 4,000 beer cans, including 80-year-old cans and ones that once held beer created by President Jimmy Carter’s brother Billy. The attached Ye Ol’ Watering Hole bar boasts an impressive menu of beers on tap and in bottles. yeolwateringhole.com/beer_can_museum.htm
